description: From Middle English skif, from Middle French esquif, from Old Italian schifo (“small boat”), from Lombardic skif (“boat”), from Proto-Germanic *skipą (“boat, ship”). Doublet of ship.

entries.meaning: A small flat-bottomed open boat with a pointed bow and square stern.
Any of various types of boats small enough for sailing or rowing by one person.
examples: I went alone into a Shepherd's boat,
A skiff that to a willow-tree was tied
Within a rocky cave, its usual home  […]

verbs.description: skiff (third-person singular simple present skiffs, present participle skiffing, simple past and past participle skiffed)

description: From Scots skiff (“light shower of rain or snow”), from skiff (“move lightly”); compare the derivative skiffle (whence English skiffle) and (English skift (“light dusting of snow”) from) Scots skift (“light shower of snow”), from skift (“move lightly”), perhaps related to shift/Old Norse skipta, or perhaps an onomatopoeic formation.

entries.meaning: A light, fleeting shower of rain or snow, or gust of wind, etc.
examples: A skiff of rain blew into the shed and the two men moved their chairs back.

entries.meaning: A (typically light) dusting of snow or ice (or dust, etc) (on ground, water, trees, etc).
examples: At sunrise there was a slight skiff of ice on some water in a bucket;  […]

verbs.description: skiff (third-person singular simple present skiffs, present participle skiffing, simple past and past participle skiffed)

entries.meaning: (dialectal, of rain or snow) To fall lightly or briefly, and lightly cover the ground (etc).
examples: We must be constantly alert to increased accident potentials in taxiing, takeoff, and landings on ice-glazed and snow-skiffed runways.

entries.meaning: An act of slightly pruning tea bushes, placing new leaves at a convenient height without removing much woody growth.

verbs.description: skiff (third-person singular simple present skiffs, present participle skiffing, simple past and past participle skiffed)

entries.meaning: To cut (a tea bush) to maintain the plucking table.
